page.title: 12 WELLESBOURNE CHURCH
page.content: One of a few extremely old buildings in the village is the Anglican Church of St.Peter. It is thought that there has been a church in Wellesbourne from Saxon times-recent excavations brought to light signs of Saxon burials. The first known record of the village was made by an Anglo-Saxon chronicler who recorded that a Witan was held in "Waleborne" in AD 862 by King Burgred of Mercia.It is assumed that any Saxon church would have been constructed of wood. The next mention of "Waleborne" is in the Domesday Book. The first stone church was built here in the late eleventh or twelfth century. Tradition attributes the building to Henri de Newburgh, one of William the Conqueror's knights, to whom the Manor of Wellesbourne was given.
